abstract.text: How cell cycle machinery regulates extracellular matrix (ECM) remodeling during cytokinesis remains poorly understood.
In the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae, the primary septum (PS), a functional equivalent of animal ECM, is synthesized during cytokinesis by the chitin synthase Chs2.
Here, we report that Dbf2, a conserved mitotic exit kinase, localizes to the division site after Chs2 and directly phosphorylates Chs2 on several residues, including Ser-217.

Both phosphodeficient (chs2-S217A) and phosphomimic (chs2-S217D) mutations cause defects in cytokinesis, suggesting that dynamic phosphorylation-dephosphorylation of Ser-217 is critical for Chs2 function.
It is striking that Chs2-S217A constricts asymmetrically with the actomyosin ring (AMR), whereas Chs2-S217D displays little or no constriction and remains highly mobile at the division site.
These data suggest that Chs2 phosphorylation by Dbf2 triggers its dissociation from the AMR during the late stage of cytokinesis.

Of interest, both chs2-S217A and chs2-S217D mutants are robustly suppressed by increased dosage of Cyk3, a cytokinesis protein that displays Dbf2-dependent localization and also stimulates Chs2-mediated chitin synthesis.
Thus Dbf2 regulates PS formation through at least two independent pathways: direct phosphorylation and Cyk3-mediated activation of Chs2.
Our study establishes a mechanism for direct cell cycle control of ECM remodeling during cytokinesis.

body_text.text: INTRODUCTION
Cytokinesis in animal and fungal cells requires spatiotemporally coordinated functions of a contractile actomyosin ring (AMR) and targeted membrane deposition.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The AMR is believed to power the ingression of the plasma membrane (PM) at the division site and guide membrane deposition (Balasubramanian et al., 2004;Fang et al., 2010;Pollard, 2010), whereas membrane deposition is be-lieved to increase surface area, as well as deliver enzymatic cargoes for localized extracellular matrix (ECM) remodeling during cytokinesis (Strickland and Burgess, 2004; Barr and Gruneberg, 2007;Fang et al., 2010).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: The core components of the AMR and the membrane-trafficking machine are conserved from yeast to human (Balasubramanian et al., 2004;Pollard, 2010).
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: Thus the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae has served as an effective model for elucidating the general mechanisms of cytokinesis.
body_text.section: INTRODUCTION

body_text.text: ECM remodeling appears to play a critical role in animal cytokinesis, as evidenced by the cytokinesis failure caused by a defect in chondroitin synthesis in Caenorhabditis elegans and mice (Mizuguchi et al., 2003;Izumikawa et al., 2010).

body_text.text: However, it remains unknown how ECM is remodeled specifically at the division site and how this process is regulated by the cell cycle machinery.

body_text.text: In budding yeast, the primary septum (PS), a specialized cell wall structure that is synthesized by the chitin synthase Chs2 during cytokinesis (Sburlati and Cabib, 1986), is conceptually similar to animal ECM.

body_text.text: Finally, deletion analyses and in vitro chitin synthase assays suggest that an N-terminal region, especially residues 197-230, of Chs2, which is located outside the catalytic domains (con1 and con2), plays an ill-defined regulatory role in its activation ( Figure 1A; Uchida et al., 1996), and this region contains two consensus sequences (RXXS) for Dbf2 (Mah et al., 2005), with serines 217 and 225 as the potential phosphorylation sites ( Figure 1A).

body_text.text: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis
To determine when and where Dbf2 might phosphorylate Chs2 during cytokinesis, we performed live-cell imaging on cells carrying both Chs2-GFP and Dbf2-mCherry.
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: As expected, Chs2 was localized to the mother-bud neck of cells at the onset of cytokinesis (Figure 1D and Supplemental Video S1;Schmidt et al., 2002;Fang et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Consistent with a previous observation (Frenz et al., 2000), Dbf2 was first localized to the spindle pole bodies (Figure 1D,arrows) and then translocated to the bud neck during cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Of importance, we found that the bulk of Dbf2 arrived at the neck 4 min after Chs2 ( Figure 1D and Supplemental Video S1).
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Chs2 was generally removed from the neck region by endocytosis within 10 min after its arrival, whereas Dbf2 remained at the neck for longer time ( Figure 1D).
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: On the basis of our previous (Fang et al., 2010;Wloka et al., 2011) and present (see Figure 4D later in the paper) studies, during the first 4 min of Chs2 localization, the AMR would have constricted >50% of its initial size.
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Thus Dbf2 likely phosphorylates Chs2 at the neck region during late stage of cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Of interest, the bulk accumulation and maintenance of Dbf2 at the neck appear to correlate with the onset of Chs2 endocytosis, which is marked by the appearance of Chs2-green fluorescent protein (GFP) "puncta" near the neck region.
body_text.section: Chs2 localizes to the division site before Dbf2 during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

To determine the functional consequence of Ser-217 and Ser-225 phosphorylation, C-terminally GFP-tagged, wild-type, phosphodeficient (chs2-S217A, chs2-S225A, chs2-AA [S217A S225A]) and phosphomimic (chs2-S217D, chs2-S225D, chs2-DD [S217D S225D]) alleles of CHS2, expressed from the native CHS2 promoter, were integrated onto the chromosome of chs2Δ cells, respectively.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: None of the chs2 phosphomutants displayed obvious defects in cell CHS2 causes severe defects in cytokinesis, including rapid and asymmetric AMR constriction, which underscores the importance of ECM remodeling during yeast cytokinesis (Bi, 2001;Schmidt et al., 2002;VerPlank and Li, 2005).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Deletion of MYO1, which encodes the sole myosin-II in budding yeast, also causes defects in cytokinesis and cell separation, including misoriented PS formation (Fang et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Thus PS formation and AMR constriction are mutually dependent (Bi, 2001;Schmidt et al., 2002;VerPlank and Li, 2005), suggesting that these processes are normally coordinated to ensure efficient cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: How PS formation is regulated by cell cycle signals remains poorly understood.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: During mitosis, Chs2 is synthesized and held at the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) through phosphorylation by CDK1 (Chuang and Schekman, 1996;Zhang et al., 2006;Teh et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: At the onset of cytokinesis, Chs2 is triggered to exit the ER by the mitotic exit network (MEN;Zhang et al., 2006;Teh et al., 2009;Chin et al., 2011) and is then delivered to the division site (or the bud neck) via the secretory pathway (Chuang and Schekman, 1996;VerPlank and Li, 2005).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: MEN consists of a Ras-related small GTPase (Tem1), protein kinases (Cdc15, Dbf2, and its homologue Dbf20), a protein phosphatase (Cdc14), and a few regulatory proteins (Balasubramanian et al., 2004;Stegmeier and Amon, 2004).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: GTP-bound Tem1 binds and recruits Cdc15 to the spindle pole bodies (SPBs; equivalent of centrosomes in animal cells), which, in turn, recruits and activates Dbf2, resulting in the release of Cdc14 from the nucleolus to the entire cell.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Cdc14 then acts on a few key substrates to down-regulate CDK1/mitotic cyclin activity, resulting in mitotic exit.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Cdc14 also directly acts on Chs2 to remove the phosphorylation by CDK1, which enables Chs2 exit from the ER for subsequent transport to the division site (Chin et al., 2011).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: MEN may also regulate cytokinesis directly at the division site, as several MEN components, including the Cdc15 and Dbf2 kinases, localize to the division site during cytokinesis (Frenz et al., 2000;Xu et al., 2000).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: However, the cytokinesis targets of these kinases are largely unknown.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: In this study, we demonstrate that Dbf2 regulates PS formation directly by phosphorylating Chs2 at a single residue, resulting in its dissociation from the AMR during late stage of cytokinesis, and that timed phosphorylation of this residue is important for PS formation during cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Several proteins, including Iqg1 (the sole IQGAP in budding yeast), Inn1, Hof1 (a F-BAR protein), and Cyk3 have been implicated in PS formation (Korinek et al., 2000;Vallen et al., 2000;Nishihama et al., 2009;Meitinger et al., 2010), but the underlying mechanism remains unknown.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Iqg1 is also required for actin ring assembly (Epp and Chant, 1997;Lippincott and Li, 1998).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Of interest, overexpression of Cyk3 suppresses the lethality and cytokinesis defects of iqg1Δ cells without restoring actin ring assembly, suggesting that Cyk3 functions in an AMR-independent process-most likely septum formation-to promote cytokinesis (Korinek et al., 2000).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Overexpression of Cyk3 also suppresses the cytokinesis and PS defects of inn1Δ cells (Nishihama et al., 2009) and causes the formation of ectopic PS-like structures in wild-type cells (Meitinger et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: These observations suggest that Cyk3 may be an activator of Chs2.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: In this study, we show that overexpression of Cyk3 robustly suppresses the growth and cytokinesis defects of the chs2 phosphomutants, further supporting the "activator" hypothesis.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: We also demonstrate that Cyk3 and Dbf2 phosphorylation define distinct mechanisms in regulating Chs2 function during cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Both phosphorylation and dephosphorylation of Ser-217 are important for cytokinesis

body_text.text: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

To explore the underlying mechanism for the cytokinesis defect caused by the chs2-S217 mutations, we first monitored the chitin level at the division site in different strains by Calcofluor staining (Pringle, 1991).
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: C-terminally GFP-tagged alleles of CHS2 (wild-type, S217A, and S217D) under control of the native promoter and carrying a centromere-based plasmid were introduced into a chs1Δ chs2Δ chs3Δ strain in which all chitin synthase genes in budding yeast had been deleted.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: The viability of the triple mutant relied solely on the introduced chs2 allele.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: The chitin levels at the division site of the chs2-S217A and chs2-S217D cells were both reduced to ∼71% of the wild-type level ( Figure 3, A and B).
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: To ensure fair comparisons, only cells with a similar size of Chs2*-GFP ring from different strains ( Figure 3A), which is indicative of a similar cell cycle stage, were included in our quantitation.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: These data suggest that phosphoregulation of Chs2 at Ser-217 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site, which may account for the cytokinesis defects caused by these mutations.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: The decreased chitin synthesis at the division site could ensue as a result of decreased catalytic activity and/or altered protein expression, localization, or dynamics.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: To distinguish these possibilities, we first measured the chitin synthase activity of the Chs2 variants in strains lacking chitin synthase I and chitin synthase III activity.

body_text.text: Chitin synthase II assays were done using membranes from chs1Δ chs3Δ rather than chs1Δ chs2Δ chs3Δ cells because the former are much healthier in growth and division (Shaw et al., 1991).

body_text.text: Furthermore, the activity of chromosomally encoded Chs2 in membranes from chs1Δ chs3Δ cells grown in minimal medium is negligible (Nagahashi et al., 1995), regardless of pretreatment with trypsin, which is known to stimulate Chs2 activity in vitro (Sburlati and Cabib, 1986;Uchida et al., 1996).

body_text.text: Membranes from each strain were assayed for chitin synthase activity with or without prior treatment by trypsin and proved to have high activity ( Figure 3C), whereas membranes from chs1Δ chs3Δ cells assayed in parallel incorporated background levels of radioactivity regardless of trypsin treatment (unpublished data).

body_text.text: It is striking that Chs2-S217A-GFP constricted asymmetrically in 79% of cells ( Figure 4, B and C, and Supplemental Video S2, middle), in comparison to 100% symmetric constriction for wild-type Chs2-GFP (Supplemental Video S2, left); in contrast, Chs2-S217D-GFP showed little or no constriction before its disappearance from the division site in 80% of cells (Supplemental Video S2, right).

body_text.text: As expected, the AMR (marked by the mCherry-tagged sole myosin-II, Myo1, in budding yeast) and Chs2-GFP always constricted together and symmetrically in wild-type cells ( Figure 4D and Supplemental Video S3, left; Fang et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: In contrast, Chs2-DD-GFP failed to follow the constriction of the AMR (Supplemental Video S3, right), suggesting the uncoupling of this mutant Chs2 from the AMR.

body_text.text: AMR constriction and disassembly appeared to be slightly longer in both Ser-217 mutants, especially in the chs2-AA mutant, than in wild-type cells ( Figure 4E).

body_text.text: The uncoupling of Chs2-S217D from the AMR is further supported by the following observations.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: First, despite similar profiles in protein expression (unpublished data) and the timing and duration of their localizations, Chs2-S217D-GFP always appeared as a broad and nonconstricting band, whereas the wild-type Chs2-GFP or Chs2-S217A-GFP appeared as a sharply focused and constricting band between the septin rings.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: Second, fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) analysis indicates that wild-type Chs2-GFP at the division site recovers quickly after bleaching during the first ∼3 min of its localization, presumably reflecting a continuous recruitment to the division site.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: Chs2-GFP is then immobilized in a myosin II-dependent manner for the rest of cytokinesis, ∼6-7 min.
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: Using this analysis on cells with already localized Chs2 and photobleaching only a portion of the Chs2*-GFP ring, we found that Chs2-S217D-GFP displayed full recovery throughout cytokinesis (Supplemental Video S4, right); in contrast, wild-type Chs2-GFP (Supplemental Video S4, left) and the majority of Chs2-S217A-GFP (Supplemental Video S4, middle) displayed no or little recovery ( Figure 5, A and B).
body_text.section: Phosphoregulation of Chs2 is important for chitin synthesis at the division site

body_text.text: Taken together, these data suggest that phosphorylation of Chs2 by Dbf2 may trigger its dissociation from the AMR during the late stage of cytokinesis.

body_text.text: Inactivation of Dbf2 causes delayed endocytic removal of Chs2 from the division site

If Chs2 were indeed a physiological substrate of Dbf2 at the division site, Chs2 would be expected to display asymmetric constriction, essentially phenocopying the chs2-S217A mutant, when Dbf2 is inactivated.
body_text.section: Inactivation of Dbf2 causes delayed endocytic removal of Chs2 from the division site

body_text.text: To test this hypothesis, we monitored at the nonpermissive temperature Chs2-GFP localization in a wild-type strain and a dbf2-Ts (temperature-sensitive) mutant carrying a GAL1 promotercontrolled allele of SIC1 s (T5V, T33V, S76A) that encodes a stable version of the CDK1 inhibitor (Meitinger et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Inactivation of Dbf2 causes delayed endocytic removal of Chs2 from the division site

body_text.text: Because Dbf2 the membranes expressing Chs2-S217D was on average ∼80% of that expressing Chs2.
body_text.section: Inactivation of Dbf2 causes delayed endocytic removal of Chs2 from the division site

body_text.text: Similar results were obtained when cells were grown in rich medium (unpublished data).
body_text.section: Inactivation of Dbf2 causes delayed endocytic removal of Chs2 from the division site

body_text.text: These data suggest that the defect in cytokinesis or chitin synthesis at the division site caused by the chs2-S217 mutations may not be fully explained by the mildly decreased catalytic activity of the mutant proteins assayed at 2 mM UDP-GlcNAc.
body_text.section: Inactivation of Dbf2 causes delayed endocytic removal of Chs2 from the division site

body_text.text: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site
To further explore the underlying mechanism for the cytokinesis defect, we monitored the dynamics of Chs2-S217A and Chs2-S217D proteins at the division site.
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Yeast strains carrying Cdc3-mCherry and different GFP-tagged alleles of CHS2 (CHS2, chs2-S217A, and chs2-S217D as the sole source of Chs2 in the cell) were grown in rich media and imaged by three-dimensional spin-disk time-lapse microscopy.
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Like wild-type Chs2-GFP, both Chs2-S217A-GFP and Chs2-S217D-GFP were localized to the bud neck around the onset of cytokinesis (Fang et al., 2010), which is marked by the splitting of the septin hourglass into two cortical rings (Cdc3-mCherry; Figure  4A; Lippincott et al., 2001).
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: The duration of Chs2-S217A-GFP and Chs2-S217D-GFP at the division is 12.8 ± 2.4 and 11.5 ± 2.0 min, respectively, slightly longer than the 10.3 ± 1.0 min for wild-type FIGURE 4: Chs2-S217A and Chs2-S217D display distinct dynamic behaviors during cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: (A) Localization patterns of Chs2-S217A and Chs2-S217D during the cell cycle.
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Cells of different strains (YO1339, YO1359, and YO1360; chs2Δ CDC3-mCherry with integrated Chs2*-GFP in at the leu2 locus) were grown in SC-LEU medium to exponential phase at 25°C and then diluted into rich media (YM-1) and grown for additional 1-2 h at 25°C before being subjected to time-lapse analysis.
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Cyk3 is a robust dosage suppressor of chs2 phosphomutants Cyk3, a cytokinesis protein that localizes to the division site in a Dbf2-dependent manner (Meitinger et al., 2010), has been implicated in PS formation, but the underlying mechanism remains unknown (Korinek et al., 2000;Nishihama et al., 2009;Meitinger et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: It is striking that high-copy CYK3 robustly suppressed the growth and cytokinesis defects of both chs2-AA and chs2-DD cells (Figure 7, A and B).
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: In contrast, high-copy CYK3 failed to rescue chs2Δ cells ( Figure 7B), suggesting that the suppression is Chs2 dependent.
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Of importance, high-copy CYK3 strongly stimulated chitin synthesis at the division site of chs1Δ chs3Δ cells in which Chs2 is the sole chitin synthase ( Figure 7C).
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Reciprocally, deletion of CYK3 exacerbated the defects of the chs2-AA and chs2-DD mutants even when the mutant cells were grown in minimal media ( Figure  7D).
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Consistent with the notion of Cyk3 acting through Chs2, cyk3Δ and chs2Δ did not produce any additive or synergistic defect in growth or cytokinesis ( Figure 7D).
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: Together these data strongly suggest that Cyk3 is an activator of Chs2 in vivo and that Cyk3 and Ser-217 phosphorylation regulate Chs2 function independently during cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Phosphorylation of Ser-217 regulates Chs2 dynamics at the division site

body_text.text: DISCUSSION
Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis
Our study demonstrated, for the first time, that Chs2 is a direct substrate of the conserved mitotic exit kinase Dbf2.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Chs2 contains six putative Dbf2-consensus sites (RXXS;Ser-21, Ser-150, Ser-217, Ser-225, Ser-256, and Ser-326;Mah et al., 2005) at its N-terminal region and two catalytically important as well as seven predicted transmembrane domains in its C-terminal region ( Figure 1A).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

ref_spans.text: Ser-21, Ser-150, Ser-217, Ser-225, Ser-256, and Ser-326;

body_text.text: In this study, we showed that both Ser-217 and Ser-225 are phosphorylated by Dbf2 in vitro.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Of importance, the same two sites were also found to be phosphorylated in vivo in global studies of phosphoproteins in budding yeast (Chi et al., 2007;Dephoure and Gygi, 2011).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Other putative Dbf2 sites and/or additional serines or threonines in the N-terminal region of Chs2 may also be phosphorylated by Dbf2, as ∼43% of phosphorylation still remained when GST-Chs2 (1-286, S217A S225A) was used as the substrate.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: However, because of the clear phenotypes displayed by the chs2-S217 mutations, our functional analysis has thus far focused on phosphorylation at this residue.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: These results, together with the observations that Chs2 and Dbf2 colocalize at the division site during cytokinesis and that Dbf2 is also implicated in PS formation (Meitinger et al., 2010), make Chs2 a highly likely substrate of Dbf2 in vivo.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Our study suggests that Ser-217 phosphorylation regulates Chs2 dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Both the phosphodeficient and the phosphomimic mutations of Ser-217 caused little defect in the catalytic activity of Chs2 in the bulk chitin synthase assay in vitro but clearly caused a 30% reduction in chitin synthesis at the division site in vivo.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Because the amount and duration of the Chs2-S217A and Chs2-S217D variants at the bud neck are similar to those of the wild-type protein, these data suggest that Ser-217 is involved in fine-tuning the inactivation simultaneously blocks both mitotic exit and cytokinesis, Sic1 overexpression was induced by adding galactose to the growth medium (see Materials and Methods for details) to force mitotic exit and trigger Chs2 translocation from the ER to the bud neck in the dbf2-mutant cells.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: This strategy provides the opportunity for assessing the specific effect of Dbf2 inactivation on Chs2 behavior at the division site.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: As expected, in wild-type cells, Chs2-GFP localized, constricted, and disappeared at or from the division site within 12 min ( Figure 6, A and B, and Supplemental Video S5, left).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: In contrast, Chs2-GFP accumulated at the division site more slowly in the dbf2-mutant than in wild-type cells, perhaps reflecting an imperfect mitotic exit forced by Sic1 overexpression ( Figure 6, A and B, and Supplemental Video S5, right).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: More important, Chs2-GFP was retained at the division site of the mutant cells for >40 min with little constriction, and its signal intensity decreased gradually over time ( Figure 6, A and B, and Supplemental Video S5, right).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: The weak signal of Chs2-GFP at the end of our imaging, coupled with its nearly nonconstrictive behavior, prevented a clear assessment of its constriction symmetry.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: However, a previous EM study indicates that 81% of the dbf2 mutant cells form an asymmetric PS (Meitinger et al., 2010), suggesting that Chs2 distribution is eventually asymmetric, which lends strong support to our hypothesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Similar to wild-type Chs2, Chs2-S217A and Chs2-S217D accumulated at and then disappeared from the division site more slowly in the dbf2-mutant than in wild-type cells, although Chs2-S217D consistently seemed to disappear more quickly ( Figure 6B).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Together these data suggest that the endocytic removal of Chs2 is delayed in the dbf2 mutant, which is largely independent of Chs2 phosphorylation by Dbf2.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: This conclusion is supported by the previous observation that accumulation of actin patches at the division site, which are required for endocytosis in budding yeast, is significantly decreased in the dbf2 mutant (Corbett et al., 2006).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Thus the MEN may also regulate the endocytic removal of Chs2 during cytokinesis by regulating actin-patch polarization at the division site.

body_text.text: displayed strikingly different behaviors at the division site, which may also partly account for their defects in cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Chs2-S217A is associated with the AMR throughout cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: In contrast, Chs2-S217D is largely uncoupled from the AMR upon its arrival at the division site.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: These observations suggest a simple model for the function of Ser-217 phosphorylation ( Figure 8A).
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: In wild-type cells, "unphosphorylated" Chs2 is delivered to the division site at the onset of cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Approximately halfway through AMR constriction, Dbf2 level reaches its peak at the bud neck, causing phosphorylation of Chs2 at Ser-217, resulting in Chs2 dissociation from the AMR.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: This dissociation may facilitate Chs2 inactivation and/or its endocytic removal from the division site.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Persistent association of Chs2 with the AMR, as shown by Chs2-S217A, somehow causes asymmetric distribution of the AMR components, resulting in asymmetric constriction.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: On the other hand, premature uncoupling of Chs2 from the AMR, as shown by Chs2-S217D, results in broad and dynamic distribution of Chs2-S217D between the septin rings, which presumably would lead to inefficient PS formation due to inaccurate placement of chitin.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Thus timed phosphorylation of Ser-217 is important for proper PS formation and cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate its dynamics and chitin synthesis at the division site during cytokinesis

body_text.text: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways
Dbf2 appears to regulate PS formation at multiple levels via distinct mechanisms ( Figure 8B).
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: First, during mitosis, Chs2 is phosphorylated by CDK1 at four residues , and this phosphorylation prevents Chs2 from prematurely exiting the ER before cytokinesis (Teh et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: During mitotic exit, Dbf2, as a part of the MEN, activates the phosphatase Cdc14, which removes the CDK1 phosphorylation from Chs2, thus promoting its exit from the ER (Chin et al., 2011).
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: Second, we show here that Dbf2 phosphorylates Chs2 directly at the division site to regulate its chitin synthase activity and also its dissociation from the AMR.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: This regulatory mechanism plays an important role in cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: Third, Dbf2 regulates PS formation indirectly by controlling Cyk3 localization to the division site (Meitinger et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: We show here that increased dosage of Cyk3 stimulates Chs2-mediated chitin synthesis and robustly suppresses chs2-AA and chs2-DD mutants, whereas deletion of CYK3 exacerbates the phenotypes of the chs2 mutants.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: These data suggest that Cyk3 is a potent activator of Chs2 in vivo and that Cyk3 and Dbf2-mediated phosphorylation regulate Chs2 function independently during cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: Fourth, Dbf2 may regulate the endocytic removal of Chs2 from the division site by regulating actin-patch polarization at the division site.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: Finally, Dbf2 is also known to phosphorylate the F-BAR protein Hof1 (Meitinger et al., 2011), which has been implicated in PS formation and/or its coordination with the AMR during cytokinesis (Vallen et al., 2000;Meitinger et al., 2010Meitinger et al., , 2011.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: It becomes increasingly clear that ECM remodeling is important for animal cytokinesis (Mizuguchi et al., 2003;Izumikawa et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: However, how the ECM is locally remodeled at the division site and how this remodeling is coupled to AMR constriction and controlled by the cell cycle machinery remain largely unknown in animal cells.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: In this study, we established a mechanism by which the conserved mitotic exit kinase Dbf2 directly phosphorylates Chs2 to regulate PS formation (or ECM remodeling) during cytokinesis in budding yeast.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: On the basis of the overall conservation in the core mechanisms of cell cycle control and cytokinesis between yeast and animal cells, we speculate that similar cell cycle regulation of ECM remodeling during cytokinesis likely exists in animal cells.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: chitin synthase activity of Chs2.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: This is consistent with previous reports that the N-terminal noncatalytic region of Chs2, including the Ser-217 residue ( Figure 1A), is involved in the regulation of Chs2 activity based on in vitro chitin assays (Uchida et al., 1996;Martinez-Rucobo et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: The underlying mechanism for the involvement of Ser-217 in this regulation remains unknown.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: One possibility is that Ser-217 might affect the putative proteolysis of Chs2 that is believed to be required for its activation in vivo (Sburlati and Cabib, 1986;Uchida et al., 1996;Martinez-Rucobo et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: However, we note that in our experiments, the chs2-S217A and chs2-S217D mutations did not significantly affect the degree to which the in vitro Chs2 activity was stimulated by trypsin.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: The moderate decrease in chitin synthesis caused by both the chs2-S217A and the chs2-S217D mutations in vivo likely explains, at least in part, their medium-dependent defects in cytokinesis.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: Presumably, cells demand more robust chitin synthesis at the division site to ensure efficient cytokinesis in the fast-growing rich media than in the slow-growing minimal media.
body_text.section: Dbf2 regulates primary septum formation through multiple pathways

body_text.text: MATERIALS AND METHODS
Strains and growth media
Yeast strains used in this study are listed in Table 1.
body_text.section: Strains and growth media

body_text.text: Standard culture media and genetic techniques were used (Guthrie and Fink, 1991).
body_text.section: Strains and growth media

body_text.text: Escherichia coli strains DH12S (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) and BL21 (DE3) (Invitrogen) were used as hosts for plasmid manipulation and recombinant protein expression, respectively.
body_text.section: Strains and growth media

body_text.text: Yeast strains were grown routinely at 25°C in synthetic complete (SC) minimal medium lacking specific amino acid(s) and/or uracil or in rich medium YM-1 (Lillie and Pringle, 1980) or yeast extract/peptone/dextrose (YPD).
body_text.section: Strains and growth media

body_text.text: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains
Common plasmid vectors used in this study include YCplac111 (CEN, LEU2), pRS314 (CEN, TRP1), pRS316 (CEN, URA3), pRS305 (integrative, LEU2), and YIplac204 (integrative, TRP1).
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: Plasmids p414ADH (CEN, TRP1;Mumberg et al., 1995) and pBK42 (2μ, CYK3, TRP1; Korinek et al., 2000) were described previously.
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: Plasmid YI-plac211-GAL1-SIC1 s (T5V, T33V, S76A)-HA (integrative, URA3; Meitinger et al., 2010; kindly supplied by Gislene Pereira, German Cancer Research Center, Heidelberg, Germany), carrying a GAL1 promoter-controlled allele of SIC1 s that encodes a stabilized protein, was cut with EcoRV and integrated at the ura3 locus of the recipient strain.
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: Plasmids YIplac128-CDC3-mCherry (integrative, LEU2; Gao et al., 2007), YIplac211-CDC3-mCherry (integrative, URA3; Fang et al., 2010), and YIplac204-CDC3-mCherry (integrative, TRP1; Wloka et al., 2011), carrying mCherry-tagged CDC3, were digested with BglII and integrated at the CDC3 locus of the recipient strains.
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: Plasmid pGEX5X-CHS2-N was constructed by cloning a BamHI-and SalI-digested (both sites were introduced in PCR primers) CHS2 fragment encoding amino acids 1-286 into the corresponding sites of pGEX5X-1 (GE Healthcare, Pittsburgh, PA).
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: YEp-pGAL1-HA3-CHS2 was constructed by inserting a 1.7-kb PCR fragment carrying TRP1-pGAL1-HA3 (Longtine et al., 1998) in front of CHS2 on plasmid pEC2 (2 μ, CHS2, URA3; Ford et al., 1996).
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: The QuikChange Multi Site-Directed Mutagenesis Kit (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, CA) was used to generate phosphodeficient mutations (S217A and/or S225A) or phosphomimic mutations (S217D and/or S225D) in CHS2 using plasmid YCp111-CHS2-GFP-KanMX6 as the template (Wloka et al., 2011).
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: Wild-type and the phosphomutant alleles of CHS2 were then subcloned into the integrative vector pRS305 (LEU2), as described previously (Wloka et al., 2011).
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: The resulting plasmid pRS305-CHS2*-GFP was digested with AflII and integrated at the leu2 locus of the recipient strains.
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: Plasmid pAG24-CYK3 was constructed by transferring CYK3 from the tiling library plasmid pGP564-CYK3 (2 μ, LEU2; Open Biosystems, Lafayette, CO) onto the Gateway vector pAG24 (2 μ, URA3) using Gateway LR Clonase II (Invitrogen, Grand Island, NY).
body_text.section: Constructions of plasmids and yeast strains

body_text.text: Microscopy

visualize cell morphology, Calcofluor-stained chitin (Pringle, 1991), and CHS2*-GFP (wild-type [WT] or phosphomutant alleles of CHS2) by differential interference contrast (DIC) and fluorescence microscopy, respectively.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: The images were acquired using Image-Pro Plus version 7.0 (Media Cybernetics, Bethesda, MD).
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: For live-cell imaging of yeast strains carrying a plasmid, cells were grown at 25°C in SC media lacking a specific amino acid to select for the presence of a plasmid.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: For imaging yeast strains carrying a chs2 phosphomutation, cells were first grown in SC-LEU medium to keep them healthy and then washed twice with rich medium YM-1 without carbon source.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Cells were then incubated further for 1-3 h at 25°C before being concentrated by centrifugation and spotted on a slab of YM-1 medium containing 2% agarose for live-cell imaging.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: For live-cell imaging at 37°C (Figure 6), the wild-type and the dbf2-1 dbf20Δ strains were grown in liquid YM-1 media containing 2% raffinose at 25°C to the exponential phase and then shifted to 37°C for additional 3 h.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: A 2.0-ml culture was then transferred to a 3.5-mm dish coated with polylysine (MatTek, Ashland, MA), which was incubated in the 37°C chamber of the microscope for 20 min to let the cells settle down.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: A 1.5-ml culture was then removed from the dish, which was followed by the addition of a 1.5-ml prewarmed YM-1 medium containing 2% raffinose, 3% galactose, and 1.5% low-melting agarose.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Images were acquired at 25 or 37°C on a spinning disk confocal microscope equipped with a Yokogawa CSU 10 scan head combined with an Olympus IX 71 microscope (Olympus, Tokyo, Japan) and an Olympus 100× objective (1.4 numerical aperture, Plan S-Apo oil immersion).
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Acquisition and hardware were controlled by MetaMorph, version 7.7 (Molecular Devices, Downingtown, PA).
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: A Hamamatsu ImagEM EMCCD camera (model C9100-13, Bridgewater, NJ) was used for capture.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Diode lasers for excitation (488 nm for GFP and 561 nm for mCherry/RFP) were housed in a launch constructed by Spectral Applied Research (Richmond Hill, Canada).
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Images were taken every minute with z-stacks ranging from 11 × 0.3 to 12 × 0.5 μm.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: A maximum projection was generated with version 7.7,or ImageJ (1.45b;National Institutes of Health,Bethesda,MD).
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: For quantification of relative chitin levels in different chs2 phosphomutants (Figure  3), the ratio between Calcofluor signal intensity at the bud neck was divided by Chs2-GFP signal intensity at the bud neck.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: For the experiments involving FRAP, cells were grown to exponential phase in SC-HIS media at 23°C.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Cells were then centrifuged and resuspended in 10 ml YM-1 medium and grown for at least another 3 h in a 50-ml flask at 25°C in a water-bath shaker.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: One milliliter of this culture was taken to concentrate the cells by centrifugation.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Cells were then spotted on YM-1 medium containing 2% agarose for FRAP and imaging analysis.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: FRAP was performed using a Micro Point computer-controlled ablation system (Photonic Instruments, St. Charles, IL) consisting of a nitrogen-pumped dye laser (wavelength, 435 nm) controlled byMetaMorph.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: In some cases, sequential photobleaching was applied Figure 5A, S217D).
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Images were captured and processed using the same microscope, camera, and software as described earlier.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Images were taken every 20 s with a z-stack consisting of 12 × 0.4 μm steps.
body_text.section: Microscopy

body_text.text: Kinase assay
GST-Chs2(1-286; WT, S217A, or S217D) fusion proteins were expressed in the E. coli strain BL21 (DE3) and purified as described previously (Fang et al., 2010).
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Dbf2-dependent phosphorylation of GST-Chs2(1-286) was performed as described previously (Mohl et al., 2009).
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: In vitro assay for Chs2 activity Cells (YO1528, YO1535, YO1536, and YO1537) were grown for 24 h at 30°C in 30 ml of SC medium supplemented with tryptophan and lysine.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Cells were sedimented by centrifugation and then resuspended in 250 ml 0.67% (wt/vol) yeast nitrogen base containing  2% (wt/vol) galactose, 1% (wt/vol) raffinose, tryptophan, and lysine.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: These cultures were incubated for 18 h at 25°C.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Mixed membranes were prepared as described previously (Orlean, 1987) with several slight modifications.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Induced cultures were harvested, and cells were washed once with 12 ml of cold water and once with 10 ml of cold 30 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5).
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: All subsequent steps were carried out on ice.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Cells were broken by vortexing with glass beads in 30 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), the beads were then washed with 30 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), and cell walls and unbroken cells were sedimented by lowspeed centrifugation.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: The pellet was washed once with 30 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5), and the combined wall-free supernatants (10 ml) were sedimented by centrifugation at 100,000 × g for 45 min at 4°C.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Mixed membranes were then homogenized in cold 30 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5) and then sedimented again at 100,000 × g.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: The washed membranes were homogenized in 0.9 ml of cold 30 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5) containing 33% (vol/vol) glycerol and then frozen at -80°C.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Protein contents of membranes were determined using the Bio-Rad DC protein assay kit (Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA).
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Trypsin treatment was carried out on 100-μl portions of mixed membranes by adding 3 μl of solutions containing 100 or 200 μg of trypsin (Sigma-Aldrich, St. Louis, MO) in 30 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5).
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: After incubation at 30°C for 10 min, trypsin digestion was stopped by adding 3 μl of solutions containing an amount of soybean trypsin inhibitor (Sigma-Aldrich) double the amount of trypsin used.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: As no-trypsin controls, samples of membranes were incubated in parallel with buffer alone for 10 min at 30°C, after which 3 μl of a solution containing 200 μg of trypsin inhibitor was added.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: The treated membranes were then placed on ice and assayed forthwith.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Assay mixtures contained, in a final volume of 50 μl, 2 mM UDP GlcNAc, UDP-[14C(U)] GlcNAc (specific activity, 300 mCi/mmol, 61,000 cpm per incubation [American Radiolabeled Chemicals, St. Louis, MO]), 32 mM GlcNAc, and 2.5 mM cobalt acetate.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Reactions were started by the addition of 20 μl of trypsin-treated or control membranes (typically containing ∼400 μg of membrane proteins) and terminated by the addition of 1 ml of cold 10% (wt/vol) trichloroacetic acid.
body_text.section: Kinase assay

body_text.text: Insoluble radioactivity was collected by filtration on GF/C discs, and the filters were washed as described previously (Orlean, 1987).
body_text.section: Kinase assay
